message: During the height of the U.S. polio epidemic, the iron lung was one of the greatest tools used to fight polio. Today, it’s the iron will of the thousands of workers and their supporters who are committed to finishing the job: https://gatesnot.es/3xTBOEh
Our foundation joined the polio fight almost 15 years ago. And in all that time, I cannot think of a more important moment than right now.
This is the greatest opportunity for innovation in human history: https://gatesnot.es/3ihTFOu
The Breakthrough Energy Catalyst program will help bring the next generation of climate solutions to market in time—and at a low enough cost—to avoid a climate disaster.

I feel very lucky to get to connect with so many extraordinary people. Whenever I have the chance, I set aside a few minutes to share what I’m learning on my personal blog. I hope that you'll join the conversation: https://gatesnot.es/facebook
A Promised Land is a fascinating look at what it’s like to steer a country through challenging times. I look forward to getting another peek behind the curtain when the second book comes out.

We need to share expertise, insights, and code on a global scale to help end Alzheimer’s and related dementias. It was great to see more than 1,200 members of the research and data science community from more than 65 countries/regions join the Alzheimer's Disease Data Initiative’s first Data Challenge, the Alzheimer’s Detection Challenge.
The journalist Elizabeth Kolbert writes about a number of the ways that people are intervening with nature, including gene drive and geoengineering. Like all of her books, it’s an enjoyable read.
Should you pick your nose?  You can read an excerpt from Matt Richtel’s fascinating book about the immune system on my blog to find the answer: https://gatesnot.es/3wQfpqL
These books gave me something to think about. I hope they do the same for you: https://gatesnot.es/3cZ3j6Q
If you’re looking for a good book to read this summer, these are some of my favorites.

One of the best parts of my job is getting to meet with smart people who are thinking about big problems. I recently hosted a cohort of graduate students for a virtual discussion on opportunities to make the education system work better for everyone. Future leaders like them make me optimistic that brighter days are ahead for America’s students and teachers.

Against the odds, Mohamed Bailor Barrie became a doctor and is helping his country recover from civil war, Ebola, and now COVID-19. This doctor’s life story is almost as remarkable as his work: https://gatesnot.es/2RtHcxS

Dr. Mohamed Bailor Barrie never thought he’d become a doctor. Growing up in poverty in northern Sierra Leone, he saw from a young age how quality health care helps people live better lives. Now, after helping his country combat Ebola and COVID-19, Dr. Barrie has become one of Sierra Leone’s health leaders. His story is truly inspiring.

How to Avoid a Climate Disaster is available now. I hope you’ll check out the book, but more importantly, I hope you’ll do what you can to help keep the planet livable for generations to come: http://b-gat.es/climatebook

Just as World War II was the defining event for my parents’ generation, the COVID-19 pandemic will define the generations living through it right now.   In our new Annual Letter, Melinda and I talk about how we hope the experience we’ve all lived through over the last year will lead to a long-term change in the way people think about global health.
A lot has changed over the last 25 years (like the connected technology that has transformed society). A lot hasn’t (like my wardrobe): https://gatesnot.es/2Jnn0JR

There’s a lot that we still don’t know about Alzheimer’s, but I’m hopeful that will change soon thanks in part to the Alzheimer’s Disease Data Initiative. ADDI will simplify how researchers and data scientists around the world work together and share knowledge: https://gatesnot.es/3kLOGow

I’m teaming up with Rashida Jones for a new podcast limited series starting Monday. Each week, we’ll talk about some of the biggest issues facing our world with special guests including authors, experts, and friends: https://gatesnot.es/3krA8uf
Understanding this concept will help the world make the most of its efforts and funding as we work together to avoid a climate disaster.

Better and cheaper batteries will hopefully make electric vehicles a realistic option for every car owner. QuantumScape (which I’m invested in both on my own and through Breakthrough Energy Ventures) is developing an exciting solution to this challenge: https://gatesnot.es/2Z567IO

Our foundation is partnering with DonorsChoose to support teachers as they get ready to go back to school—in whatever form that takes—and will boost your donations to the classroom project of your choice today.
This hero is playing a critical role in Kenya’s preparations to tackle COVID-19 by scaling up medical oxygen supplies that will be needed to keep the most critically ill patients alive.
Here are five books to read this summer if you want to learn more about pandemics or are looking for a distraction: https://gatesnot.es/3dh5KQc
Melinda recommended that I read The Choice, and I’m glad she did. I think many people will find comfort right now from Dr. Edith Eger's suggestions on how to handle difficult situations.
The 1918 influenza outbreak is the closest comparison to what we’re living through right now. John Barry does a great job explaining the realities and lessons of that devastating pandemic.

Most of my conversations these days are about COVID-19 and how we can stem the tide, but I’m also often asked about what I am reading and watching. Here are my 2020 summer book recommendations (plus a few other ideas for things to do at home).
I’m hopeful that this program will improve our understanding of the coronavirus outbreak in Seattle and provide valuable information about the virus for other communities around the world.
Class of 2020, these are not easy times. But we will get through them. And with your leadership, the world will be stronger than before.

There are over 100 different coronavirus vaccine candidates in the works. These candidates take a variety of approaches to protecting the body against COVID-19. To understand what exactly that means, it’s helpful to remember how the human immune system works: https://gatesnot.es/3bX0Ozk

Humankind has never had a more urgent task than creating broad immunity for coronavirus. It’s going to require a global cooperative effort like the world has never seen. But I know we’ll get it done. There’s simply no alternative.
We don't yet have all the tools we need to stop the novel coronavirus and safely re-open the economy. But they are on the horizon.
Nicholas Kristof does an amazing job capturing the heroism of the health care workers on the front lines of the coronavirus fight.
I always enjoy chatting with Trevor Noah, even though we had to sit a little bit further apart than usual this time.
Thank you to all of the health care workers who are making heroic efforts to test and treat patients across the United States and the world.
I’m excited to join the Khan Academy Daily Homeroom today to talk about the incredible ways parents, teachers, and students are coming together to keep learning while schools are closed.

There’s no question the United States missed the opportunity to get ahead of the novel coronavirus. But the window for making important decisions hasn’t closed. The choices we and our leaders make now will have an enormous impact.

I’m inspired by the generosity of everyone who has contributed to this effort to help keep kids learning at home. Thank you to DonorsChoose and especially the educators who are doing amazing things for their students every day.
There are few people I’ve learned more from over the years–especially about viruses–than Peter Piot. This Q&A with him is an excellent, easy-to-understand primer on #COVID19: https://b-gat.es/39rQ0Ho

Lots of people in Seattle have asked how they can help those impacted by #COVID19 locally. All In Seattle has done a great job identifying organizations who are already on the ground and deploying resources quickly to help our friends and neighbors: https://allinseattle.org/

Teachers are doing incredible work to keep kids learning while at home. To help get supplies to the teachers and families most in need, Melinda and I will double your impact, up to $1 million total, when you give to DonorsChoose coronavirus relief effort today and tomorrow.
I’m connecting live with Chris Anderson and Whitney Pennington Rodgers to talk about what our healthcare systems need to tackle the #COVID19 pandemic and prepare for future epidemics.
Thanks Reddit for joining me yesterday to discuss the #COVID19 pandemic and what we can do to prevent the next one. Here's a recap of the conversation: https://gatesnot.es/2wm2xyN

We don’t yet have all the tools we need to fight COVID-19. This is an important step toward having treatments, while we also explore vaccines and diagnostics. Thanks to Wellcome Trust and Mastercard for launching this effort with us.
COVID-19 could be a once-in-a-century pandemic, but the good news is that there are steps we can take now to slow its impact and help us respond more effectively when the next epidemic arrives.

1 in 4 children under five in South Africa are stunted. The Grow Great Campaign is empowering new and pregnant moms to keep their children healthy. Here’s why I’m optimistic that they can make an impact: https://gatesnot.es/2HZfroE

Melinda and I have met many stunted children in our travels. It’s heartbreaking and utterly preventable. Dr. Kopano Matlwa is leading an incredible effort to eliminate child stunting from South Africa over the next decade.

As Melinda and I reflected on our foundation’s work over the last 20 years in our latest annual letter, one person kept coming up: my dad. The foundation wouldn’t be what it is without him, and we wouldn’t be who we are without his leadership and inspiration.

No one will be hit harder by climate change than smallholder farmers. If we’re going to avoid a climate disaster, we need to help them adapt to a warmer world. Here’s how we’re approaching that challenge: https://gatesnot.es/32awGfT

When Warren Buffett donated the bulk of his fortune to our foundation and joined us as a partner in its work, he urged us to “swing for the fences.” All these years later, that advice still guides how we think about our philanthropy: https://gatesnot.es/32bH1Ix #TBT

North-Grand High School was once ranked among the worst schools in Chicago. Today, it’s among the best—with 95 percent of its freshman on-track to graduate. I visited in 2018 as part of our foundation’s work to help create opportunities for schools to learn from each other. Read why we’re investing in these Networks for School Improvement: https://gatesnot.es/2Pi3i2j

Vaccines are a miracle. But how exactly do they work? I explain the science behind vaccines and why our foundation’s investment in Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance is one of the best we’ve ever made: https://gatesnot.es/37uMfA5

Improvements in health are key to lifting people out of poverty. As people become healthier, their lives improve in other ways. And the world becomes better and more equal as a result: https://gatesnot.es/3bySiH7

When we first started our foundation, Melinda and I were optimistic about the power of innovation to drive progress—and excited about the role we could play by taking risks to unlock it. Twenty years later, we’re just as optimistic, and we’re still swinging for the fences: https://gatesnot.es/37hA35C

This year marks the 20th anniversary of our foundation. Despite how much things have changed in that time, our belief that every person deserves the chance to live a healthy and productive life is still our most important driving principle.   In our 2020 annual letter, Melinda Gates and I reflect on the first two decades of our foundation and look forward to the next 20 years.

I’m excited to team up with Roger Federer again for the Match in Africa Friday in Cape Town. Playing alongside Roger is always a thrill, and I can’t wait to face off against Rafa Nadal and Trevor Noah.  .
If the world keeps up the fight against these neglected tropical diseases, we can improve the lives of millions of families: https://gatesnot.es/2uNKwYS #WorldNTDDay
I know I'm biased, but I think "The Moment of Lift" is a wise, honest, and moving book about how empowering women lifts up everyone.

For twenty years, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance has worked to ensure that every child in the world is protected from preventable diseases. The results are incredible. But their work is far from done. There are still too many children -- many living in some of the hardest-to-reach places on the planet -- who aren’t getting basic vaccines. Gavi is the best tool we have to reach them.  #VaccinesWork
I had a fascinating conversation with Vaclav Smil about what bacteria, babies, empires, and economies all have in common: https://gatesnot.es/38ujZyA
These global health heroes have helped Bangladesh become a model for other countries for how to respond to infectious disease outbreaks.
It’s encouraging to see these results. Typhoid is especially deadly for young children, and a vaccine like this has the potential to save millions of lives.
Thanks to the work of this father–daughter dynamic duo, Bangladesh is moving toward a future of fewer disease outbreaks and more children reaching their fifth birthday.
If your New Year’s resolution is to be healthier in 2020, this book is a good place to start.
I’m glad Beautiful News - Daily is highlighting some of the amazing things happening in the world.
Vaclav Smil is one of my favorite thinkers, and I couldn’t wait to get my hands on his new book about the growth of *everything*.
What’s next for our foundation? I’m particularly excited about what the next year could mean for one of the best buys in global health: vaccines.

I’ve read a lot of books about history over the years, and These Truths by Jill Lepore is the most honest and unflinching account of the American story I’ve ever seen. It’s also one of the most beautifully written.

December is a great time to take stock of everything you’ve done over the last twelve months—including all of the books you’ve read. I found these books to be really clever and engaging. I hope you them find as intriguing as I did: https://gatesnot.es/2Ek7dFR

Back in my early Microsoft days, I routinely pulled all-nighters when we had to deliver a piece of software. I even stayed up two nights in a row on occasion (I don’t recommend that). This book taught me a lot about the importance of a better night's sleep.

I was deeply moved by Tayari Jones's story of a married couple whose lives get torn apart by an incident of injustice. The book is so well-written that you’ll find yourself sucked into it despite the heavy subject matter.

One of the things I've enjoyed most as a father is watching my children get curious about a topic and then seeing how their knowledge deepens and grows. In her wonderful new book, Diane Tavenner offers advice about how parents can support their child’s independent growth.
I’ve read a lot of great books this year. Here are some I think you’ll enjoy reading over the holidays.
I'm a big fan of Silicon Valley and was excited when they asked me to appear in the series finale tonight. #AlwaysBlue
Technology has made it faster and easier than ever before for people everywhere to give. I’m inspired by how many people from all over the world participate in GivingTuesday. https://b-gat.es/2Lkkulx
I was impressed to see the tremendous impact Gestamp’s apprenticeship program is having on students and their community.
This #WorldAIDSDay, I’m excited about breakthroughs in treating and preventing HIV thanks to organizations like The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.
My father is one of the wisest, kindest, and most fun people I know. Happy birthday, Dad!
At Gestamp, an auto parts maker in Chattanooga, Tennessee, I saw how the factory is putting high school students on a path to opportunity.
Dr. LeAndrea Ware is one of the most energetic school leaders I’ve ever met. Her positivity is infectious. It’s no wonder she was recently named the Tennessee principal of the year.
We’re getting closer to having a blood test for Alzheimer’s – which could help doctors detect and diagnose the disease earlier:
I recently visited The Howard School in Chattanooga, Tennessee and was inspired to see how the community has come together to help improve their school.

You could find wild poliovirus in 125 countries in 1988. Today, it exists in just two. And more than 18 million people are walking today who would otherwise have been paralyzed by polio. Here’s why we aren’t done yet: https://b-gat.es/348ut50

Polio persists in some of the most complex and challenging places on earth. But I’m optimistic we will eradicate it thanks to GPEI’s persistence and creativity—and to the continued support of partners, donors, and leaders.

The more I’ve learned about Alzheimer’s disease, the more I’ve come to admire the volunteers who participate in clinical trials, and their caregivers too.  "Turning Point" directed by James Keach (www.brightfocus.org/turningpoint) profiles patients, caregivers, and medical professionals in the fight against Alzheimer’s disease.

I’m optimistic about the future because I believe in the power of innovation and the talent of the people devoting their ideas, their resources, and even their lives to solving the world’s greatest challenges. Become a Gates Notes Insider to join the conversation: https://gatesnot.es/2rjGk1w

One of the many awful things about watching someone you love struggle with Alzheimer’s is the feeling of helplessness. You keep thinking that there must be something more you can do. Here's one option.

We have cut the number of child deaths in half over the last 20 years. New tools like these precision maps from Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME) will help us cut child mortality in half again by 2030.
To prevent the worst effects of climate change, we need to get to zero net greenhouse gas emissions in every sector of the economy within 50 years.
I always like to try out a new TV show or two when I’m on the road. What should I watch next? I set up an Ask on Likewise to collect your recommendations: https://b-gat.es/36cN15z

Cement is a massive emitter of greenhouse gases. A company in Canada (which I’ve helped fund through Breakthrough Energy Ventures) discovered an innovative way to reduce cement's carbon footprint: https://b-gat.es/31SIcLj

Melinda and I feel pressure to make every dollar and every day count, which is why we say no to a lot more opportunities than we say yes to. Working with partners towards a world without polio has been a fight worth every dollar.

Of all the people who will be affected by climate change, those in poor countries will be at the greatest risk in the years ahead. I’m excited about innovations aimed at making sure that the world’s poorest people can grow enough food to feed their families and to earn an income.

The world is facing a crisis at the dinner table — we’ll need to produce 60 to 70 percent more food by 2050. At the same time, climate change is making it even harder to feed the world. But there’s hope. I’m optimistic about the progress being made by the RIPE project to more efficiently turn the sun’s energy into food.

Stephen Hawking and I saw each other several times over the years, and we mostly talked about physics. Trust me: if you’re as interested in physics as I am and you have an opportunity to talk to Professor Hawking about his work, you take it. But I also learned a lot from him about how to shape the future: https://b-gat.es/2nZm83K

The odds of dying of AIDS in South Africa are less than half what they were at the peak. That progress wouldn’t have been possible without The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria and other global health organizations. Even more progress is possible if we keep up the fight: https://b-gat.es/35MeFpM

A more diverse drug pipeline increases our odds of discovering an Alzheimer’s breakthrough. I’m excited to see this news about a promising starting point for the development of new therapeutic strategies.
The world has committed more to the Global Fund than ever before. That’s incredible news. We can’t stop the fight until we eliminate these diseases.

In Afghanistan, one of the last countries with polio, vaccine acceptance rates have reached 98% thanks to the tireless work of female health workers. Their increased involvement and passion is why polio eradication is within reach in Afghanistan.

I wasn’t exactly surprised by this map. In my travels, I’ve seen that talent is evenly distributed, but opportunity is not. The best way for a country to unlock innovation is to invest in the health and education of its people.

My friend Aliko Dangote and I like to geek out over things that make some people’s eyes glaze over. On his most recent visit to Seattle, we talked about how iodized salt could reduce malnutrition in his home country of Nigeria: https://b-gat.es/35erd9b

I’m lucky to have known Stephen Hawking – and I was deeply honored to be chosen to give this year’s Hawking Fellowship Lecture. As remarkable as the professor’s contributions to the field of physics were, I believe his biggest accomplishment was inspiring the world to believe in the magic of science and research. He reminded us to “look up at the stars and not down at [our] feet.” He taught us all that, if humanity remains focused on expanding what is possible, progress will come: https://b-gat.es/2VnBjQc

My belief in the power of innovation has been a constant in my life, starting from the time I fell in love with software in high school to my work today at our foundation.  Here is the story of the day I knew what I wanted to do for the rest of my life and the influence of someone who’s been a critical guide along the way: https://b-gat.es/2Mj1vYc

The Economist is right: climate change touches everything and everyone—and, unfairly, the poor and marginalized have the most to lose.  But if we take this challenge seriously and invest in the right mix of solutions, we can still create a carbon-free future.   I highly recommend you read this issue.

Melinda's work on behalf of women and girls around the world inspires me every day. She's committing $1 billion over the next ten years to increasing women's power and influence in the United States. Because #EqualityCantWait.

Aliko Dangote and I have a lot in common. We both started successful businesses in the late 1970s, and for our second act in life, we both chose to start foundations. Melinda and I are lucky to have him as a partner (and friend!) in our work: https://b-gat.es/2ofuYdq

It's really incredible how much time and effort goes into producing a documentary like the new Netflix series I participated in. I shared more about the experience on my blog: https://b-gat.es/2mYiMgp

An estimated 395,000 babies were born around the world on the first day of 2019. What are the odds they will grow up healthy and educated?   Join me live as I talk about accelerating progress in global health and development with a few of my fellow Goalkeepers.
Melinda and I are back in New York for our annual Goalkeepers event. Join us live as PM Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand and PM Pedro Sanchez of Spain kick off #Goalkeepers19.

Tomorrow is our foundation’s annual Goalkeepers event — a day when we celebrate progress towards The Global Goals. I invited one of this year’s Goalkeepers, Dr. Elvis Eze, to share his story on my blog. I’m glad he said yes: https://b-gat.es/2mSBeqE
My dad has always been an amazing role model, and he still influences my life and work every day. See more deleted scenes and read exclusive stories like this on my blog: https://b-gat.es/2Nstd7M
The docuseries about my life and work is out today. I hope you’ll check it out on Netflix — and then read some of the stories that didn’t make the cut on my blog.

It is a terrible injustice that the people who suﬀer the most from climate change are the poorest farmers in the world who did nothing to cause it. Ethiopia’s successful approach to building resilience offers hope: https://b-gat.es/3082S54

Melinda and I started out ahead. But hundreds of millions of people around the world have to overcome hurdle after hurdle to be successful. Read about how advocates are working to even the odds for everyone.
Awoke Mose is a smallholder farmer in Ethiopia who farms teff, wheat, chickpeas, and corn. He works diligently on his one-hectare plot saving whatever money he can for his children’s education.
Meet Serin Dossa, a corn meal street seller in Nigeria. She provides for her three children and unemployed husband, hoping that, one day, her family can live a better life.

Petronilla Malesi is a street seller who lives on $2 a day. After her four grandchildren were orphaned, Petronilla took on the weight of being their sole provider by selling popsicles in Kibera, one of Nairobi’s poorest slums.

Ndikumana Gervais is a fisherman from Rwanda who lives on less than $2 a day. With help from a local microsaving organization and continuous hard work, he is hopeful that he can soon give his children a better life.

Today, one of the biggest challenges facing Alzheimer’s researchers is finding patients who can benefit from novel therapies before it’s too late. AI is showing a lot of promise in helping to detect Alzheimer’s far earlier than current methods. I'm eager to see how it could change how we better understand and fight the disease.

Here’s a remarkable statistic: Nearly 1.1 billion fewer people are living in extreme poverty today than in 1990. Even with all this progress, the number of people living on less than $2 a day is over 700 million.   It’s difficult for most of us—especially those living in the wealthiest countries—to imagine what life is like on less than $2 a day.  That’s why I’d like to invite you to listen to the voices of some of the world’s poorest people answer that question for themselves. I hope you will be touched by their stories, their challenges, and their dreams for better lives—and then ask what you can do to help the millions of people like them.

Steel is amazing. It’s cheap, strong, and infinitely recyclable.   But it’s also one of biggest contributor of greenhouse gases. Don’t despair. Companies like Boston Metal are working to change the game: https://b-gat.es/2HPDfLV

As part of my job, I get to learn about lots of different plans for dealing with climate change.  Here are four innovative approaches scientists and entrepreneurs are working on that I’m excited about: https://b-gat.es/2zHZQpa
Today is a very special day for a friend who always makes me laugh.  Happy 89th birthday, Warren! I look forward to making many more memories.

Whenever I hear an idea for what we can do to keep global warming in check—whether it’s over a conference table or a cheeseburger—I always ask this question: “What’s your plan for steel?”  I know it sounds like an odd thing to say, but it opens the door to an important subject.
It’s easy to see why Robert Hand was named 2019 Teacher of the Year in my home state of Washington. He makes sure all of his students have what they need to succeed in life: https://b-gat.es/2HkA5Qd
Tomorrow is #WorldMosquitoDay, when we recognize all of our partners and grantees who are fighting against the world’s deadliest animal and the diseases it spreads: https://b-gat.es/2Ziurbn

I never really learned how to cook, but if you invite me over to your house for dinner, you can count on me to do the dishes. I’m finally learning my way around the kitchen, though, thanks to Robert Hand: https://b-gat.es/2Ze5M7I
Happy birthday to my favorite person. Melinda, you’ve had an amazing year. I can’t wait to see how you top it.

Robert Hand is the kind of teacher that any kid would love to have. He was nice enough to visit my office earlier this year and show me how to make one of his students’ favorite dishes: barbecue chicken.

Melinda and I are big fans of DonorsChoose.org, and we were thrilled to learn that W. Kamau Bell is, too. The three of us are coming together to support teachers around the country as they prepare to go back to school. Today, when you support a project, your donation will get a 50% boost from our foundation: https://b-gat.es/2Z3hAtu

With school starting up again, teachers have enough things to think about. Having access to the right supplies shouldn’t be one of them. That’s why I’m thrilled to announce that today, when you give to DonorsChoose.org, our foundation will boost your donation by 50%.   I hope you’ll join us in supporting teachers.

Being poor isn’t cheap. It’s hundreds of times more expensive to use charging stations than it is to charge a phone at home. That’s just one of the hidden costs of unreliable electricity: https://b-gat.es/2GY1lUv
It’s National Book Lovers Day! Here are some of the best books I’ve read so far this year: https://b-gat.es/2YTC3Nh

Increasing access to electricity is critical to helping people lift themselves out of poverty. That’s why I’m making investments in innovations that will help power the world without contributing to climate change: https://b-gat.es/2YOarsZ
It will take the U.S. another 208 years to achieve gender equality.   That’s 208 years too late. Equality can’t wait: https://b-gat.es/31ffkwO
Nearly one billion people live in energy poverty. Explore my 360-degree video to see who has access to electricity and who doesn’t (and what we can do about it).
It’s amazing to see what people can achieve when they’re able to lead healthy lives. Just ask the women polo players of Manipur, India.
We can feed the world and fight climate change at the same time. Here is a shortlist of some of the breakthrough technologies that can help us get there.
We need bold new ideas to fight Alzheimer’s. That’s why I’m joining a group of philanthropists to invest in finding a reliable, affordable, and easy-to-use diagnostic for the disease.
I couldn’t help but feel optimistic after reading this book. It’s a fascinating look at why humans have more in common than we might think.

I usually wait until the end of the year to share good news that you might have missed, but I couldn’t resist sharing this list from Positive News (check out #14!). Which story has inspired you the most so far this year?

Can you imagine an aircraft engine in your car? The Advanced Research Projects Agency - Energy (ARPA-E) Summit is one of the coolest places to learn about new energy tech. The Breakthrough Energy team came back with lots of new ideas and insights from this year’s event.

“Fathers who help unlock their daughter’s potential, standing up for their rights and raising them to believe they have them, bring prosperity and happiness to their entire families.” I enjoyed this essay from Ziauddin Yousafzai about what he’s learned from being Malala’s dad. #MalalaDay

The people who will suffer most from climate change are the ones least responsible for it. I’m inspired by a research center called CIMMYT that is helping poor farmers adapt to climate change: https://b-gat.es/2S8sjNx
The world needs to invest in research that will help poor farmers adapt to climate change. And no other institution has done more to deliver these innovations as CGIAR.

I first met Paul Allen when I was in 8th grade and he was a sophomore (although he looks like he’s my teacher in this photo). This teletype is the thing that brought us together. I’m so glad that it did: https://b-gat.es/2Xq7Dqh

I was honored to talk about my late friend Paul Allen at the Forbes Philanthropy Summit. He was one of the most thoughtful, brilliant, and curious people I’ve ever met. I wish more people had the chance to know him like I did.

If you have the willingness to learn about a problem and the talent to help solve it, you can make a remarkable difference in the world. Just ask former NASA engineer William Wu: https://b-gat.es/2Jc3N9Y
I love talking about toilets. National Geographic recently wrote about two that I think could change the world: https://b-gat.es/2WZnITr
I encourage software developers, inventors, and scientists to consider how they can use their skills to fight inequity.
When Goodreads asked me to share my top summer reading recommendations, it was hard to narrow down the list.

The older I get, the more I treasure any time I get to spend with my dad. He is all the things I strive to be: a fantastic husband, a loving father, an effective philanthropist, and an engaged citizen of the world. Happy #fathersday, Dad.
Thank you for being a friend, Warren: https://b-gat.es/2Z823VM #BestFriendsDay
It's no secret that my friend Warren Buffett has a sweet tooth (he sometimes eats Oreos for breakfast). Now that he knows how to make a Blizzard, I suspect it will be on his breakfast menu too.

My friend Warren and I recently picked up a shift at Dairy Queen. I don’t think either of us will win “employee of the month” any time soon, but we learned a lot about what great customer service looks like: https://b-gat.es/2ERNi1D

Stopping Alzheimer’s is a real chicken and egg problem. Discovering a treatment requires lots of clinical trials, but it's difficult to enroll people without a way to identify if they have the disease.   There is good news, though: thanks to significant breakthroughs over the last couple years, we’re finally within reach of a reliable, affordable, and easy-to-use way to diagnose Alzheimer’s.

Imagine for a moment that you’re one of the one billion people in the world who don’t have an official proof of identify. Without a way to prove who you are, you can’t access many of the rights and services most of us take for granted. For the last decade, my friend Nandan Nilekani has been working to make these “invisible people,” as he calls them, visible by giving them access to official identification. Nandan was responsible for launching India’s biometric ID system, the largest of its kind.

In the 1970s, two Colombian pediatricians were facing a big problem. A lack of incubators made survival for preterm infants extremely challenging.   Looking for a solution, they drew inspiration from an unlikely source: kangaroos. Their approach has been shown to reduce newborn mortality by more than half: https://b-gat.es/2O30Klw

Last Mile Health CEO Dr. Raj Panjabi may be too humble to call himself a hero, but I think he fits the bill. He has dedicated his life to delivering basic health care to people who live beyond the reach of the health system: https://b-gat.es/2uM30Gs

In 2012, my dad went to visit Nelson Mandela in South Africa along with President Carter. Mandela took them to a clinic that cared for infants born with HIV. As reporters and photographers looked on, he picked up one of the babies and held it in his arms. President Carter and my dad did the same. The next day, the image of all three men cradling HIV-positive babies was broadcast throughout South Africa. It sent a powerful message: that people did not need to be afraid of touching a person with HIV. I love this photo, because it reminds me of the indelible example that Mandela set for all of us. #mandeladay

When Raj Panjabi returned to his home country of Liberia, he was shocked to learn that there were only 51 doctors for a country of 4 million people. That would be the equivalent of about four thousand doctors in the entire U.S.  Dr. Panjabi didn’t shy away from this daunting reality. Instead, he and his colleagues set out to recruit, train, and equip an army of health workers who could reach the most remote areas of the country. Today marks one year since our dear friend Hans Rosling’s passing. In the last year of his life, Hans sent us a very touching letter. You may have seen in the news that elected officials in Washington, D.C., are working on next year’s federal budget. One of the ideas that has been floated is to make deep cuts in foreign aid—the investments that America makes to help other countries fight poverty and disease.  That would be a big mistake.  For one thing, these programs amount to less than 1 percent of the federal budget. For anyone worried about the budget deficit, cutting 1 percent will not make a dent.  More importantly, these programs give American taxpayers a phenomenal return on investment, one of the best anywhere in government.  They do this in three ways:  1. Making Americans safer and the world more stable  2. Creating jobs at home and promote trading partners that will buy American goods  3. Saving lives and building up health systems so other countries can take better care of their people  Together these three points make the strategic case for aid—the argument that aid helps the countries that give it as well as those that receive it.  These are the arguments I have been making in Washington on behalf of American aid. All reasons why I believe this money is well-spent and ought to be maintained.

On July 12, 2016, a baby boy was born to a family outside Johannesburg in South Africa. Three days later, he died. His parents graciously gave me permission to be present at his autopsy.  It’s not enough to know that a newborn died from asphyxia or sepsis or prematurity; we need to find out what causes these conditions, so we can find the tools to prevent them. Fortunately, one researcher figured out how to do a minimally invasive autopsy, and when parents were asked if they would allow that procedure for their babies, a huge majority said yes.  The research is crucial to saving more newborns. It is the most high-stakes work we fund: solving mysteries to save lives.

Richard Feynman has a lot in common with all the amazing teachers I’ve met in schools across the country. You walk into their classroom and immediately feel the energy—the way they engage their students—and their passion for whatever subject they’re teaching.   These teachers aren’t as famous as Feynman, but they deserve just as much respect and admiration. If they gave a Nobel for making high school algebra exciting and fun, I know a few teachers I would nominate: http://b-gat.es/1P0QXWG

Students often ask me what they should study if they want the best shot at a great career. Computer science is always near the top of my list.   It will be at the forefront of innovation in biology, robotics, and more. Any country that wants to keep innovating needs to invest in computer science.   Plus it’s really fun—and it teaches you how to think.   My hope is that the #CSForAll Initiative will help ensure that every student will have access to computer science.

Ricky Thacker’s uniquely designed classroom is one example of what makes him such a great teacher. Last summer, he attended an education conference where a presenter displayed two photos: one of a classroom in 1915, and one from 2015.   Ricky was immediately struck that the setup of American classrooms has not really changed in the last 100 years. Most students still sit in straight rows with a teacher at the front of the class.   When he returned to Betsy Layne, he decided it was time to bring his classroom into the 21st century. He wanted to create a space that put students at the center: http://b-gat.es/1UWzmCR

We’ve only eradicated one disease in history: smallpox.   Fortunately, thanks in large part to the leadership of President Jimmy Carter and the Carter Center, guinea worm will soon be gone.

When I first walked into Ricky Thacker’s classroom, I was surprised by how unusual it looks. There are no desks. White boards hang from every wall. The entire room is painted bright orange and yellow.   Ricky stood in the middle of the room, with students rushing around him learning about x and y axes. The Rosie Effect, by Graeme Simsion is the hilarious follow-up to The Rosie Project, one of the best novels I've read in ages. There’s no sophomore slump here. Simsion brings back some of the best characters and gags from the first novel while also bringing in enough new elements to keep it fresh. It’s a funny novel that also made me think about relationships: what makes them work and how we have to keep investing time and energy to make them better. A sweet, entertaining, and thought-provoking book.

MYTH: FOREIGN AID IS A BIG WASTE  Foreign aid is a fantastic investment. It saves and improves lives, laying the groundwork for long-term economic progress.  But I worry about the myth that aid doesn't work. It gives political leaders an excuse to try to cut back on it—and that would mean fewer lives are saved, and more time before countries can become self-sufficient.  So I want to take on a few of the criticisms I often hear about aid.  The Amount of Aid  Many people think that development aid is a large part of rich countries’ budgets. When pollsters ask Americans what share of the budget goes to aid, the average response is “25 percent.” When asked how much the government should spend, people tend to say “10 percent.”  Here’s the actual number: Less than 1 percent.  One percent of the U.S. budget is about $30 billion a year. Of that, roughly $11 billion is spent on health: vaccines, bed nets, family planning, drugs to keep people with HIV alive, and so on. (The rest goes to things like building schools, roads, and irrigation systems.)  I don’t want to imply that $11 billion a year isn't a lot of money. But to put it in perspective, it’s about $30 for every American. Imagine that the income tax form asked, “Can we use $30 of the taxes you’re already paying to protect 120 children from measles?” Would you check yes or no?  Corruption  Another criticism is that aid gets wasted on corruption. It is true that when health aid is stolen or wasted, it costs lives. We need to root out fraud and squeeze more out of every dollar.  But we should also remember the relative size of the problem. Small-scale corruption, such as a government official who puts in for phony travel expenses, is an inefficiency that amounts to a tax on aid. Suppose it amounts to a 2 percent tax on the cost of saving a life. We should try to reduce that. But if we can’t, should we stop trying to save lives?  There is a double standard at work here. I've heard people calling on the government to shut down some aid program if one dollar of corruption is found. On the other hand, four of the past seven governors of Illinois have gone to prison for corruption, and to my knowledge no one has demanded that Illinois schools be shut down or its highways closed.  Aid Dependence  Another argument from critics is that aid keeps countries dependent on generosity from outsiders.  This argument makes several mistakes. First, it lumps different kinds of aid together. It doesn’t differentiate aid that is sent directly to governments from funding that is used for research into new tools like vaccines and seeds.   Second, this argument misses all the countries that have graduated from being aid recipients. Here is a list of former major recipients that have grown so much that they receive hardly any aid today: Botswana, Morocco, Brazil, Mexico, Chile, Costa Rica, Peru, Thailand, Mauritius, Singapore, and Malaysia.   Critics are right to say there is no definitive proof that aid drives economic growth. However, we do know that aid drives improvements in health, agriculture, and infrastructure that correlate strongly with growth in the long run. Health aid saves lives and allows children to develop mentally and physically, which will pay off within a generation.   A baby born in 1960 had an 18 percent chance of dying before her fifth birthday. For a child born today, the odds are less than 5 percent. In 2035, they will be 1.6 percent. I can’t think of any other 75-year improvement in human welfare that would even come close. Does that sound like waste to you?

Over the next week I will be writing about three myths that block progress for the poor. Melinda and I take on these myths in our 2014 Annual Letter. I hope you’ll give it a read.    MYTH ONE: Poor countries are doomed to stay poor.    When Melinda and I visited Mexico City in 1987, we were surprised by the poverty we witnessed. There was no running water in most homes, so we saw people trekking long distances by bike or on foot to fill up water jugs. It reminded us of scenes we had seen in rural Africa. The guy who ran Microsoft’s Mexico City office would send his kids back to the United States for checkups to make sure the smog wasn't making them sick.    Today, the city is mind-blowingly different. There are high-rise buildings, new roads, modern bridges, and the air is cleaner. There are still pockets of poverty, but by and large when I visit there now I think, “Wow, most people who live here are middle-class. What a miracle.” You can see a similar transformations in Nairobi, New Delhi, Shanghai and many more cities around the world.     Despite all of the signs of progress around the world, one of the most deeply ingrained myths I hear is that poor countries are doomed to stay poor. I hear this about a lot of places, but most often about African nations.  The fact is, they haven’t stayed poor. Incomes and other measures of human welfare are rising almost everywhere, including in Africa. And the percentage of very poor people has dropped by more than half since 1990.     Since 1960, China’s real income per person has gone up eight-fold. India’s has quadrupled, Brazil’s has almost quintupled, and the small country of Botswana, with shrewd management of its mineral resources, has seen a thirty-fold increase. A new class of middle-income nations that barely existed 50 years ago now includes more than half the world's population.    The same is true for Africa. Income per person has climbed by two thirds since 1998 – from just over $1,300 then to nearly $2,200 today. Seven of the 10 fastest-growing economies of the past half-decade are in Africa. Africa has also made big strides in health and education. Fewer people are hungry, and more people have good nutrition.    While many of the countries we used to call poor now have thriving economies, one billion people still live in extreme poverty around the world, so it’s not time to celebrate.    But I am optimistic enough that I am willing to make a prediction: By 2035, there will be almost no poor countries left in the world. A few countries may be held back by war, politics (North Korea, for example), or geography (landlocked nations in central Africa). And inequality will still be a problem: There will be poor people in every region, though most of them will live in countries that are self-sufficient. But every nation in South America, Asia, and Central America (with the possible exception of Haiti), and most in coastal Africa, will have joined the ranks of today’s middle-income nations. More than 70 percent of countries will have a higher per-person income than China does today. Nearly 90 percent will have a higher income than India does today.    By 2035, desperately poor countries will become the exception rather than the rule. Billions of people will have been lifted out of extreme poverty. It will be a remarkable achievement.

It was an honor to meet President Nelson Mandela a number of times. We left each visit inspired and more optimistic about the opportunity to improve the lives of the poor throughout the world.  From prisoner to president, Nelson Mandela was tireless in his pursuit of equality and justice for all people.  President Mandela was a remarkable example to us, to our foundation, and to the whole world thanks to a life imbued with courage, dedication and compassion.  Our thoughts and prayers are with Graça Machel and President Mandela’s family.  We join with the people of South Africa in grieving the loss of this extraordinary and inspirational leader. You may have heard of Black Friday and Cyber Monday. There's another day you might want to know about: GivingTuesday.    The idea is pretty straightforward. On the Tuesday after Thanksgiving, shoppers take a break from their gift-buying and donate what they can to charity. You can go to http://www.givingtuesday.org and find thousands of groups to support, from a local home for neglected children to a disaster-relief program in the Philippines.      Giving Tuesday is part of a larger trend that I find very encouraging: Technology is creating the opportunity to make philanthropy both more efficient and more effective.    Just as online technology is helping business reach millions of new potential customers in a more targeted way, it's also helping non-profits reach a huge pool of potential new donors. Suppose you're a small organization that serves meals to homeless people in Baltimore. In the past, you would've had almost no chance of getting promoted by a global organization like the United Nations Foundation (which is one of the Giving Tuesday partners) or attention from a celebrity with a big Facebook or Instagram following. But by joining Giving Tuesday, you can get all these things, at essentially no cost, and which boosts your exposure and the odds that you'll connect with someone who wants to support you.    DonorsChoose.org and Catapult - where Melinda Gates has curated a list of her favorite projects - are two other sites that are helping nonprofits connect with new donors. charity: water lets donors host their own fundraising campaign (like a bake sale or marathon) and then learn in detail about the projects they're funding.    The spread of online information isn't just good for charities. It's also good for donors. You can go to a site like Charity Navigator, which evaluates nonprofits on their financial health as well as the amount of information they share about their work. GreatNonprofits is similar but also lets people who donate or get services write about their experience. Good nonprofits crave this kind of feedback, so it's terrific that technology is finally helping them get it.    Of course, the Internet has not suddenly solved every problem in philanthropy. For example, while it's great that donors can go online and find out about an organization's overhead costs, what about its results? How do they compare to other groups doing similar work? Some of the ratings sites plan to try to answer these questions, which is good news. At the same time, nonprofits shouldn't be forced to divert too much of their time and money into filling out reports. It's a tricky balance and we shouldn't go overboard.    But the opportunities are growing to connect with donors and make philanthropy even more effective. If you run a nonprofit, I'd encourage you to make the most of these opportunities. If you're a donor, I hope you'll make it a priority to support organizations that are transparent and effective. You may have to spend a few extra minutes doing research, but the more you know, the more impact your dollars will have. You can also use the ratings sites to help charities improve your experience as a donor. If their Web site made it especially easy to give, let them know. But if they made you regret it by bombarding you with spam and junk mail, let them know that too.    I often talk about the need for philanthropy to target our greatest needs and spark long-lasting change. Effective philanthropy is no longer the sole province of big foundations that employ teams of experts. With the technology we have today, and with the innovations that are still to come, anyone with an Internet connection, a few dollars to give, and the time to do a little digging can become a more-informed donor. These days, effective philanthropy is for everyone.

You might have read that vaccine prices are high in the developing world because there’s not enough demand for them there. That’s not quite true - there is plenty of demand. The problem is that, because the poor can’t afford expensive vaccines, the markets don’t respond to their demand.   This is the story of an amazing partnership that is helping to meet demand in the developing world for the penta vaccine, which protects a child against five killer diseases. Since 2000, partners have worked together to drive the price down by 66 percent. We're estimating that by 2020, this work can save more than 7 million lives. http://b-gat.es/17JJ44K

Ghana is making rapid advances on its path to development. There are now more mobile phones than people, the infant mortality rate has dropped 48% since 1990 and Ghana’s institutions are reducing inequity and promoting economic growth. That’s what I call progress!
In Ghana, I met with a group of small farmers participating in a program to grow food and sell it to the local school.

After visiting the Awutu health clinic in Ghana, I’m impressed by their work on Malaria. Cases in this region have dropped by nearly 4,000 since 2011. One case is too many, but there are important lessons to learn from what is working.

Ghana is a country poised to meet the challenges of the 21st century. Its strong immunization system built upon thorough data collection, accountability and community outreach is just one of the many reasons why I am very excited about the future of this dynamic country.

I’m in Accra, Ghana to learn about some of the incredible progress being made on global health issues. Over the next few days I’ll share some of my experiences in this vibrant country. Why am I so excited? Ghana may be a good model for other countries. Learn why:

The fact that large populations in India, China and Africa are emerging from poverty is fantastic news. It also presents us with new challenges. As these populations earn better incomes, they will want to consume more proteins and meat and deserve the opportunity to do just that. We need to start thinking about the Future of Food if we are going to feed 9 billion people in a way that does not destroy our environment.

Last January, after years of battling the disease, India celebrated a full year without a single case of polio. Most people expected India to be the most difficult place to eliminate polio. Stopping the circulation of the virus everywhere in the country was the eradication initiative's biggest accomplishment in the past decade. Learn more in my Annual Letter:    http://b-gat.es/UBDzSm

Ethiopia has reduced child death by 60%. That is phenomenal. Watch this video to learn more:

Traditionally, Ethiopian parents didn't name their children until a full month after birth because so many children used to die in the first weeks of life.   I can’t think of a better example of the progress Ethiopia has made than the story of Sebsebila Nassir. Sebsebila received quality maternal care thanks to the commitment Ethiopia’s government made to reduce infant mortality. Because of that commitment, she didn’t hesitate to name her baby the same day she was born. Read more about Ethiopia’s battle against infant mortality in my Annual Letter:

I was honored to give the Richard Dimbleby lecture this past week. My talk focused on the world’s battle against polio and how we can end this devastating disease once and for all. It will be re-broadcast today at 19:32 GMT and tomorrow at 22:32 GMT on the BBC World Service.

Hans Rosling and the amazing Gapminder team demonstrate how foreign aid is SO VERY critical in places like Ethiopia, where child mortality has started to become dramatically less common.  ---------------------------- Hans Rosling shows how measurement reveals incredible progress in saving the lives of children in what were once labeled "developing countries." If the few countries that still have high child mortality rates can follow the path of Ethiopia, preventable child deaths may be history by 2030. We must continue to closely measure this progress.  Video created in partnership between The Gates Notes and Gapminder. License: Creative Commons 3.0.

In previous Annual Letters, I have focused on the power of innovation to reduce hunger, poverty and disease. But any innovation—whether it’s a new vaccine or an improved seed—can’t have an impact unless it reaches the people who will benefit from it. That’s why this year I wrote about how innovations in measurement are critical to finding new, effective ways to deliver these tools and services to the clinics, family farms and classrooms that need them.

An innovation—whether it’s a new vaccine or an improved seed—can’t have an impact unless it reaches the people who will benefit from it. And it can’t reach those people unless innovations in measurement tell us where those people are and how effectively we are reaching them. Great submissions coming in for My Hope for 2030! Lots of people sharing powerful videos & photos. 2012 was a good year in terms of improvements on some key global health issues. From progress on Millennium Development Goals, to decreasing rates of child mortality, the World Health Organization shares the highlights. Good insight in to what went well and what else needs to be done:

Kofi Annan’s book about his decade as Secretary-General of the United Nations is an illuminating read about what might be the world’s most challenging diplomatic job. Annan also played an important role in creating The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria—the main funding partner for efforts to fight three of the world’s biggest health challenges. For anybody who wants to understand the complexities of the Secretary General, this book is an illuminating read.
Melinda guest edited the BBC Radio 4 “Today” program. It had some great conversations with people like Warren Buffet and David Cameron. Highlights:
Most people think you are either born with a good memory or not. After reading “Moonwalking with Einstein,” you might reconsider. Another one of my favorite reads in 2012:

One Billion Hungry: Can We Feed the World? was one of the best books I read in 2012.  Gordon Conway lays out the formidable challenges we face in feeding the world by 2050. History shows that we can reduce hunger and poverty, but to make a lasting difference we will need to help smallholder farmers sustainably increase their productivity.

Ezra Vogel’s “Deng Xiaoping and the Transformation of China” was a great read about a complicated man. Deng Xiaoping was responsible for moving millions out of extreme poverty but also the massacre at Tiananmen Square. My Review of Vogel’s book:

We all want our donations to do the most good possible.  Charity Navigator is a terrific tool for anyone hoping to make giving easier, more effective and rewarding.

Will you support a charity this Holiday season? Do you need to buy gifts as well? You can do both at the same time with Gifts that Give.  They let you support causes that you care about, while shopping for gifts that you would normally purchase. The site makes giving simple and can share the profits of your purchases  with over 1.2 million charitable organizations.

How do you figure out what really works?  GreatNonprofits has an innovative plan: give donors, volunteers and the recipients of aid a place to freely exchange ideas and success stories.   This is the wave of the future: real-time feedback to help nonprofits improve their work.

When people ask Melinda and me, “How can I help?” our answer is, “Follow your passions.” When you find the cause that inspires you, and the way to get involved, that engages your heart and your mind—you will make a big difference in the world. Digital mapping, GPS technology and indispensable local knowledge can help improve the effectiveness of polio eradication efforts in northern Nigeria. Why?   http://b-gat.es/Tt8eJT

Health workers in Nigeria are using a Geographic Information System (GIS) to help collect data and target specific areas for immunization efforts in the fight to eradicate polio. Nigeria is one of the three remaining polio-endemic countries, and this system is helping to improve the quality of maps that tell vaccinators where to go. They are also using GPS technology to monitor the movement of vaccination teams. This kind of surveillance reduces the chances a team will miss an area that still harbors the disease. I’m optimistic that it will really help vaccinators cover the “last mile” in the delivery of polio vaccines. Read more http://b-gat.es/Ux4OXE

Teachers: It’s exciting to announce the launch our educator beta program of the Big History Project. The Big History Project seeks to summarize and relate all of human knowledge and show students “the big picture” in a compelling way that works with a variety of learning styles. Learn more and explore your options.

It may not have been as exciting as a U2 concert, but I had a great time in Europe with Bono. We met with European leaders and stressed how important foreign aid is to combating the world’s worst diseases and how smart aid can lift millions out of poverty.   http://b-gat.es/RXJP3k

Real progress is being made in Africa, and commitments like those from President Jonathan of Nigeria promise more. He has launched an ambitious program to save 1,000,000 lives by focusing on maternal and child welfare. His leadership and vision are inspirational.

Europe’s leaders are in the midst of crucial budget negotiations. Some leaders are proposing cuts to lifesaving EU aid programs that have helped enroll more than 9 million children in primary education, vaccinate 5.5 million children against measles, and connect more than 31 million people to clean water.  If you live in the EU, you can be a lifesaver. Join 100,000 fellow activists and let EU leaders know that you want them to continue aid to help the world’s poorest.

Bono and I were in Paris this week, talking about the importance of foreign aid with senior French officials, including France’s new President, Francois Hollande. We’re excited and thankful that France remains committed to aid, even in these tough budgetary times.

I get to hang out with a lot of very cool and inspiring people. But none more so than Bono. I first met him a decade ago, and we’ve worked together a lot since. But people are still curious about our connection. I guess we might seem like a strange pair. We are. Melinda and I have many friends, allies and valued partners in our philanthropic work, but few as creative, energetic and inspiring as Bono.
I’m very pleased with our meetings. They took place in spectacular surroundings, but the focus was on the poor. And that made for a very good first day in Europe.

President Hollande was clear he remains committed to aid, and that he is an advocate for both the effectiveness of foreign aid when it is carefully done, and the responsibility developed countries have in working with the developing world.
We spent the better part of our first day of the trip meeting with senior French officials, including France’s new president, Francois Hollande.
I’m in Europe this week, traveling part of the time with Bono, to talk about the importance and effectiveness of foreign aid.

I’m in Europe this week for stops in London and Paris. I’m traveling part of the time with Bono - to meet with government leaders and policy makers of countries that are key contributors to global health and development work. We spent the better part of our first day meeting with senior French officials, including France’s new president, Francois Hollande.

Social Venture Partners Seattle’s Social Innovation Fast Pitch offers non-profit and for-profit innovators a program to develop and sharpen plans and presentations of their work through workshops, coaching, and mentoring. Teams learn and draw from one another’s knowledge and passion as they compete for over $200,000 in grants and investments.   Its always exciting to see young people take on the world’s most difficult problems, applying their talents to tough challenges in the marketplace.
Why go to the Gulf? So much history, so much to learn from our partners.

Polio has almost been eradicated from the face of the Earth – but not quite, not yet. In New York on Thursday, heads of state and other world leaders came together to recommit to finally closing the door on this disease. It was an honor to be there.     http://b-gat.es/QwvASv

While at UN Week, I spent some time with Sandro Rosell, the President of FC Barcelona and the FC Barcelona Foundation.  They have been tremendous partners in using their club and its worldwide fan base to raise awareness of polio with their “More than a Goal” campaign.
For me, Wednesday afternoon at the UN General Assembly was a great chance to catch up with some of our allies from all over who are working on the front lines of global health and development.
We are 99% of the way to eradicating #polio - forever. What’s holding us back? What else can we do?    http://b-gat.es/SBvjiG

When the UN event on ending polio is one of the hottest tickets in town, you know you are witnessing an extraordinary moment of global solidarity. And the timing couldn’t be better, because we’re at a particularly critical juncture in the fight.  For me, it’s proven to be the best job in the world: as thrilling and humbling as anything I’ve ever done.

Some photos from the first trip Melinda and I took to Africa. Africa is a beautiful place and it was a phenomenal trip. We went there to see the animals. But we were surprised to see such deep poverty. It had a profound impact on us, and led to our commitment to helping those most in need.

Melinda and I have the honor and the responsibility to return to society the resources we have received in the best way we know how. But you do not need to be the chair of a large foundation to have an impact on the world. Whether your chief resource is volunteer-time or hard earned dollars, for a relatively small investment, catalytic philanthropy can make a big impact.   For me, it’s proven to be the best job in the world: as thrilling and humbling as anything I’ve ever done.

If you think of the arrow of time, as pointing towards potential improvement, your mentality is very different than if you think, "Okay, we're fallen.  You know, things are always going to get worse."    In my work on global health, you always have to first confront people with the fact that there's been this unbelievable improvement. They find it very surprising, at first. There really is this progression that someone can be part of and speaks to a more positive way of looking at the world.
The summer vacation gave me a chance to finish some of the books I’d been eager to read. Take a look at a few of my favorites:
Joshua Foer raises fascinating questions about memory in his new book, “Moonwalking with Einstein”. For example, we tend to remember things we care about, but what about the rest? Read my review:

Great video about Ambri which is developing liquid metal batteries that will help renewable energy overcome its biggest challenge: intermittency.   This exciting technology, developed by Don Sadoway and his team at MIT, has the potential to be an energy game changer.
Real Pakistani health success: Children missed for 3 years finally get polio, measles, penta vaccines.

I’m incredibly excited about the Big History Project – a phenomenal way to learn about 13.7 billion years of history. David Christian, whose lectures were my introduction to the topic says,   “You have to do something that may seem completely impossible. You have to survey the whole history of the universe. So let’s do it!”  I couldn't agree more.

LearnZillion offers 1500+ free, Common Core lessons created by some of the country’s best public and private school teachers.  Thanks to the work of 120+ amazing teachers this summer, any teacher can plan his/her lessons—for an entire week, month or year—using a single platform.    It’s a great resource for teachers to get ideas for their own classes, use directly with their students, or just study instructional strategies to learn from these master-teachers who participated in the project.

Amanda Bennett’s memoir, The Cost of Hope tells a very human story about her husband Terence and his battle against a rare form of kidney cancer. It is filled with moments of anguish, grief and love AND it tries to draw attention to what she discovers is a flawed health care system.   It is a perfect example about why all of the hard decisions about health care spending are just that.

Innovations in science and technology have brought phenomenal benefits to people around the world, but our fundamental approach to sanitation hasn’t changed in 200 years. If we apply the same kind of creative thinking to an everyday challenge like dealing with human waste, we could help 40 percent of the world’s population live healthier, better lives.
Did you know that 2.5 billion people don’t have access to a proper toilet? This infographic shows why we need to reinvent the toilet so all people worldwide have access to sanitation services.

As I told investors at the Khosla Ventures Summit, anyone looking for a great investment opportunity should investigate the market for a toilet that doesn’t require water to flush or costly sewer and treatment systems to handle waste. It truly is the business opportunity of a lifetime. And it would help solve one of the world’s biggest challenges—safe, affordable, sustainable toilets for 7 billion people.
At the Reinvent the Toilet Fair, the winning toilet uses solar power and an electrochemical reactor. Incredible. See all of the impressive finalists in this photo gallery.  http://b-gat.es/N4zEnt
The modern toilet was invented in 1775, and we haven’t made much progress since then…until today. Check out the winner of our latest "Reinvent the Toilet Challenge"
4 out of 10 people don’t have a safe way to poop! 2.5 billion people don’t have access to #toilets. We can do more to fight disease by reinventing the toilet. See this video to learn more.

The latest data on Climate change is compelling: Richard Muller, whose analytic rigor is well respected and who's been skeptical in the past, has produced some important data which supports the idea of climate change influenced by humans. While his data hasn’t been peer-reviewed, he has made the data available for criticism, emphasizing the need for transparency. I'm encouraged that we can shift the debate back to solid science informed by high-quality data. I'm even more impressed that Muller remained open minded enough that strong data could sway his understanding of a complicated problem. Take a look at an Op-Ed he wrote for the NYT:

I go to India at least once a year to see the progress of the work our foundation is doing there. Throughout this week, I’ll be posting several videos here from my most recent visit. First up: an overview of the trip and a detailed look at my visit to the Serum Institute, an impressive facility responsible for producing vaccines for 2 out of 3 children around the world.

India is “this close” to eradicating polio thanks to Amitabh Bachchan and countless other health workers, political leaders and, most importantly, parents. I am truly inspired by the amazing work going on in India today.

First up: an overview of the trip trip and detailed look at visit to Serum Institute, an impressive facility responsible for producing vaccines for 2 out of 3 children around the world.

“…the economic lives of lower-income people in any country tend to be extremely volatile…” Katherine Boo's book, “Behind the Beautiful Forevers”, really captures this volatility. It’s a powerful read for anyone who wants to understand what life is like in one of the world’s many urban slums. It brought up a few questions for me, about her approach and what she took away from her experiences in Mumbai. Katherine answered a few of these questions in a guest blog post on my website.
People ask me why I went to India again this year and why I like to go back at least once every year. There are so many reasons. Here's a short video with just a few thoughts about why I went.
Simple checklists are saving lives in India. Atul Gawande's work is a great reminder that innovations don't have to be complex to have enormous impact.

One reason I was very excited to be visiting India again recently was to get a chance to check on our foundation’s efforts to help halt the spread of HIV/AIDS there. We seem to be making good progress and learning lessons that could be helpful in other countries. More on Avahan, one program that is making a big difference.

Back from another amazing trip to India, with much more to share in the coming days. For now, see photos of an Aarti ceremony that I participated in at an innovative community-led center that focuses on HIV prevention. Part of a larger program called Avahan, this center includes an impressive member-run microfinance bank. Learn more about this great self-help success story, and see photo galleries from the rest of my trip on my website: http://b-gat.es/L2uUA1

Yesterday in Delhi, I toured the world-class campus of the Serum Institute and met with a delegation from Pakistan focused on polio eradication. Their resolve in the face of difficult circumstances is impressive.

Katherine Boo’s unvarnished, first-hand account of life in one of India’s slums is incredible. Vital reading if you want to understand urban poverty. I’m an optimistic person by nature, but was grounded reading Boo’s book. It’s a reminder of the complex and persistent problems the world’s poorest face. And of the work ahead.

I spent May 30 in Uttar Pradesh visiting with the families, organizations, and government officials who are working together to improve lives in the state. The best way to understand the work that needs to be done is to visit. I felt lucky to spend the first day of this trip to India in U.P.

Later in the day I visited the Serum Institute of India. This is an amazing company, and its facilities would be considered state of the art anywhere in the world. Serum produces low-cost, high-quality vaccines used in 140 countries around the world. It started out in 1966 to manufacture low-cost vaccines for Indian use. But over the years, Serum’s low-cost vaccines have literally transformed the world of health. By lowering the cost, you expand the reach of these miracle drugs.  ---------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. Learn more about the trip on my website: http://b-gat.es/MdnhKA.

The upside is that it’s the height of the mango season right now, and I’ve been lucky enough to get them at just about every meal.  They’re spectacular.  ---------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. Learn more about the trip on my website: http://b-gat.es/MdnhKA.

I was really honored to be welcomed by Dr. Cyrus Poonawalla and his son Adar Poonawalla.  Dr. Poonawalla started Serum with his brother, and his commitment to low-cost access has made a huge difference to millions of people around the world.  This year, Serum will ship a billion doses of vaccines worldwide.  ---------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. My second full day in India started with a meeting with a high-level delegation from Pakistan of people working on eradicating polio in their country. The delegation was led by Shannaz Wazir Ali, who is Prime Minister Syed Yousaf Raza Gillani’s Special Assistant for polio eradication. I’d met her early last year in Dubai, to talk about ridding Pakistan of this terrible disease, and so it was good to catch up on progress made in the intervening months.  ------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. Learn more about the trip on my website: http://b-gat.es/MdnhKA.

A couple of people have asked about the weather (44 Celsius – 112 Fahrenheit today).  I’ll admit – as a guy from Seattle – that the temperatures have been a challenge.   ---------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. Learn more about the trip on my website: http://b-gat.es/MdnhKA.

I was able to meet with a number of Serum’s top scientists and got to look at their impressive manufacturing line. I was particularly happy to see their work on the Pentavalent vaccines. This is a 5-in-1 vaccine given to children to protect them from life-threatening haemophilus influenza type B, diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus and hepatitis B. Serum’s work has dramatically lowered the cost of these vaccines (and a great many others) and is a true contribution by India to the well-being of the world.  ---------------------------------  May 31, 2012: I visited with a delegation from Pakistan to discuss the progress against polio, as well as the founders and scientists of the Serum Institute and that manufactures low cost vaccinations and is transforming the world of health. I just finished Behind the Beautiful Forevers, Katherine Boo’s book on the slums of Mumbai, and so was thinking about this part of the trip before I got here. I’ve been to poor areas many times, but I don’t think anything can completely prepare you for a place like Ujariaon. Good water is rare and open defecation is the rule. It is a stark reminder that even in the cities, there is much work to be done.  -------------------------------  May 30, 2012: I visited with families, health organizations, and government officials to build an understanding of how we can reach further to provide critical health services in the state of Uttar Pradesh. All kids deserve to get vaccines. This is a huge victory to protect all children.

As the World Health Assembly meets this week, Secretary Ki-moon is calling attention to an important fact: This year, fewer than 100 people were paralyzed by polio. If we do not focus on eradication, a renewed outbreak could paralyze as many as 1 million people within a decade. The international community must work together to eradicate polio for good. We are *this close* to wiping out the disease, but without a concentrated and coordinated effort, the world remains vulnerable.
The decline in African child mortality is speeding up, falling twice as fast as during the early 2000s. This really IS one of the best stories in development.
